data.title: From the Archives, 1978: Sir Robert Menzies dies, aged 83
data.meta_description: On May 15, 1978, Sir Robert Menzies died in Melbourne. He twice served as Australia's Prime Minister, and played a central role in the creation of the Liberal Party of Australia
data.text:
Menzies managed to sell the party to Australians as non-sectional, and he also gave it its pragmatism. He realised, as he said, that the conservative forces had been too often in the position "of the man who says 'no’."

Perhaps Menzies' strongest personal trait was his ability to learn from his mistakes.

When he was Prime Minister first, from April 1939 to August 1941, he failed disastrously, humiliatingly. He was unpopular with his colleagues and the people; he could not attain or hold the support of the Country Party.

Eventually he was forced to resign from the coalition's leadership, to be replaced by the Country Party's Arthur Fadden, whose government was quickly defeated in Parliament.

A proud and imperious man, Menzies acknowledged years later: “I was still in that state of mind in which to be logical is to be right, and to be right is its own justification. I had yet to acquire the common touch ..."

He never did acquire that touch, but transformed himself into a father figure, respected if not liked by colleagues, admired by the voters.

"Politicians, like athletes, seldom come back once they start to slide to oblivion. Menzies proved an exception," wrote veteran journalist, the late Don Whittington.

He overcame some early predictions that the new Liberal Party "can't win with Menzies", forged a strong Opposition, won Government in 1949, and built a lasting pact with the Country Party.

Significantly, at his final Press conference, Menzies named creation of the Liberal Party and maintenance of the CP alliance as the two achievements on the political side which gave him most satisfaction.

When the Menzies Government is looked back on, perhaps its most remarkable feature will be its longevity.

It was a period of strong and stable rule, of some solid but few outstanding achievements.

Menzies was a ruthless and skilled politician, but also had his share of luck.

In the Iate 1940s, Labor's unpopularity was indispensable to his return to power.

In 1954 his use of the Petrov defection was a combination of ingenuity, unscrupulousness and good timing which helped pull off a dicey election.

In 1961 his long-established Government held on by the barest one seat margin after bad economic decisions swung public support away.

Disarray and bad leadership in the Labor Party of the 50s and 60s made Menzies' ability seem greatness, and the healthy, international and economic growth made government much easier than in the seventies.

Menzies' total supremacy over his Government eventually did a disservice to the party he had fathered.

His first Prime Ministership made him determined to protect his own flank. Even when his authority was unquestioned, he encouraged or shunted out men of ability who might be rivals.
